unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Playing Giddy Up - Go: Standard Deviation of Proportion
question_text:
Giddy Up - Go is a hot new game app that can be downloaded on smartphones. Researchers wanted to know what proportion of smartphone users have downloaded the app. They believe that the actual proportion is $0.10$ and have decided to investigate.
After surveying a random sample of $225$ smartphone users, the researchers determined that $27$ had downloaded the app.
In constructing a confidence interval, which of the following shows how to calculate the standard deviation of the sample proportion?
solution:
The reference materials provided with the AP Exam give the following formula for calculating the standard deviation of a sample proportion:

$$\sqrt { \dfrac { (p)(1-p) }{ n } } $$

...where $p$ represents the population proportion and $n$ represents the sample size.

When constructing a confidence interval, we do not know the population proportion, but are trying to produce an estimate. Also, we are not trying to test our sample proportion against a hypothesized proportion.

Therefore, when constructing a confidence interval, we use the observed proportion and the following, slightly adjusted formula for standard deviation.

$$\sqrt { \dfrac { (\hat{p})(1-\hat{p}) }{ n } } $$

...where $\hat{p}$ represents the sample (observed) proportion.

First, calculate $\hat{p}$ as follows:

$$\dfrac{27}{225}=0.12$$

Then, filling in the formula:

$$\sqrt { \dfrac { (0.12)(0.88) }{ 225 } } $$

...we obtain Choice 'B' as the correct answer.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because it uses the hypothesized proportion in the calculation.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because it uses an incorrect formula. Always check the reference materials if you are unsure of the correct formula!

Choices 'D' and 'E' are incorrect. Both use the formula for calculating the standard deviation of a binomial random variable which focuses on counts - not proportions. Since we are looking for the standard deviation of a proportion, using this formula is not appropriate.
